title.narrative: OUTPUT 2.2: HIGH QUALITY EDUCATION, INCLUDING ALTERNATIVE PATHWAYS

description.narrative: Output 2.2: Improved capacity of the Ministry of Education and Training to provide high quality education, including alternative pathways., which contributes to Access To Quality Learning Opportunities, Access To Quality Learning Opportunities (Covid), Cross-Sectoral - Social And Behaviour Change, Evaluation, Health And Development In Early Childhood And Adolescence, Immunization Services As Part Of Primary Health Care, Learning, Skills, Participation And Engagement, Learning, Skills, Participation And Engagement (Covid), Mental Health And Psychosocial Well-Being, Nutrition Of Adolescents And Women, Research. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Community Engagement, Social And Behaviour Change, Data, Research, Evaluation And Knowledge Management, Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Evaluations, Research And Data, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: Outcome 2:By the end of 2023, adolescents (10 to 19 years), particularly the most vulnerable, benefit from gender-responsive quality health, HIV, learning and protection services.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Output 2.2: Improved capacity of the Ministry of Education and Training to provide high quality education, including alternativepathways.

description.narrative: Schools were reopened safely through UNICEF’s support to the Ministry of Education and Training (MOET) in capacity building of COVID focal points in all schools; ;procurement of 934,370 facemasks to benefit all enrolled children from pre-primary to secondary schools; and installation of 745 handwashing stations in 40% ;of the schools in the country that benefit 251,100 learners (130,929 girls) including those with disabilities. In addition, 34,040 children were supported with accelerated learning in-school and 10,074 more children at the community level. Furthermore, 3,483 most vulnerable lower secondary children were supported with school fees subsidies. | Status:Partially met | As-of Date:14/12/2021
